subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Group
msgSnippet: Ed: Thanks for your e-mail.  I have attached a response in Read s Alphabet to your attachment.  Hope you have fun reading it. My computer insisted in saving it
messageBody:
Ed:
 
Thanks for your e-mail.  I have attached a response in Read's Alphabet to your attachment.  Hope you have fun reading it. My computer insisted in saving it in Word 6.0.  I am not a Word user myself so I hope this does not cause you a problem in viewing the file.
 
I'll talk about which characters need work when I have a little more time.  Jon (last name escapes me at the moment, but he lives in Virginia, USA) put Jerome together, and my understanding is it was a first attempt on his part to work with fonts so my hat is off to him.   I haven't heard anything from him in quite some time, but he is still listed as a member of the group.  When Jon uploaded Jerome, I was ecstatic.  I had tried to interest someone in the Shavian group  in designing a Quikscript font, but no one seemed interested.  It was so cool to be able to type in Quikscript (I still prefer this name, although I acquiesced in calling this group Read_Alphabet to give recognition to Kingsley Read.)  after years of being the only person I knew who was still using it.
 
I corresponded with Sidney briefly years ago.  (Aside:  Sidney & Jon, I must apologize to both of you for not responding to your letters last year.  I was so busy at the time, I never got to them despite my good intentions.)  It is gratifying to see that he too has maintained his interest after so long a time.

 

 

Paige Gabhart
----- Original Message -----
From: Ed Gaddy
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, February 13, 2002 12:00 AM
Subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] Group

Hi,

 

I’m new to this group and thought perhaps its activity had died down. So it was good to hear from both Sidney and Paige.

 

I’ve kept a very simple journal in Quikscript off and on for some time. I’m hoping that some correspondence in Quikscript will improve my skills a bit and give me a “feel” for a better way to write in English.

 

In response to some of Paige’s comments, I have fooled around making some very crude computer fonts using an inexpensive program called Font Creator Program (FCP). With this program, I’ve had difficulty designing the characters so that the cursor went to its intended and usual position. Perhaps this is what ails Jerome.

 

Paige, can you tell me which characters you think are malformed? I could have a go at improving them - - - but please do not get your hopes very high. Whoever made Jerome is better at making fonts than I am.

 

If anyone would care to, I’d like to carry on some short, simple, correspondence in Quikscript. So as a start, I’ve attached a Word document with a couple of sentences in Quikscript using Jerome. Despite Paige’s comments, I can’t even read my own Quikscript with Jerome unless I keep the characters from running together. I do this by going to Word’s

 

Format/Font/Character Spacing/Spacing menu and expanding by about 1.2 points.

 

 

 

Best Wishes,

 

 

e-mail: ed.gaddy@...

phone:  301 390 5115

 

-----Original Message-----
From: Sidney Tanaban [mailto:sidban2@...]
Sent: Monday, February 11, 2002 6:59 PM
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Group

 

Hi
I saw your message.  I know both Shaws and Kwikskript but have not seen any Kwikskrit on internet.  I would appreciate you letting me know if there is.  Like you I have not had much opportunity to read it and that is as important as writing it.  One way is by letter and I tried somewhat to promote that but no one was interested.  Like you I am not software savvy and have no idea how to make up a page for Kwikskript.  Please keep in touch if anyone is capable of doing something in this area.

Sid


On Mon, 11 February 2002, "pgabhart" wrote:

>
> Welcome to all new members of the group and hello again to those who
> have been members for awhile.  Life has not left me much time in
> recent months to do much with Read_Alphabet.  I am trying to correct
> that to some degree now.  I am still having a little trouble with my
> e-mail -- my network at my office is not currently operational -- so
> do not despair if I do not respond to an e-mail as quickly as you
> would have liked.  I will respond eventually.
>
> I have been using Read's Alphabet, AKA Quikscript,for roughly 26
> years.  I have only had an e-mail from one other person who has been
> aware of the alphabet for that length of time, and he seems to
> alternate between Read's Alphabet and Shavian.  If you or anyone you
> know of has been using it for an extended period of time, let us hear
> from you.
>
> I am a firm believer in the utility of Read's Alphabet as well as its
> viability as an alternative alphabet that could help people in their
> daily lives just as Kingsley Read suggested in the Quikscript Manual.
>
> A little background on myself:  I am an attorney in private practice,
> who considers himself semi-computer literate.  By this I mean I am
> not knowledgable about specialized areas of computer science, such as
> designing fonts from scratch.  On the other hand, I am not afraid to
> open up my CPU to add hardware, and I remember what a DOS command
> is.  Hence, the semi-literate designation.  I bring this up because
> there are computer skills that I do not have, nor do I have the time
> to learn them in the near future, that would greatly enhance this
> site.  I do not doubt there are people in this group who already
> possess some of these skills and who, with a modest investment of
> time, could help us to turn this site into an attractive spot to
> attract more Read's Alphabet users.
>
> To give you some idea of what I am talking about:  Here are several
> things I would like to see appear on this site.
> 1.  A copy of the Quikscript manual.  It is not copyrighted so there
> is no legal prohibition I am aware of that would prevent us from
> posting it.
> 2.  Texts written in Read's Alphabet.  These should be varying
> lengths and levels of complexity.  They could be original or copies
> of literary works in the public domain.
> 3.  A practice area for people to write back and forth to each other
> in Read's Alphabet to gain experience in reading other people's
> script.  I must admit that even after years of occasional use, I am
> not as fluent at reading Read's Alphabet as I am at reading roman. 
> Practice makes perfect, after all.  I read roman everyday.  I cannot
> say that about Read's Alphabet.  It is hard to get practice when the
> only person that knows the script is yourself.  I know by experience,
> it is not easy to get casual acquaintances to learn Read's Alphabet,
> but the internet gives us the chance to reach people from around the
> globe who are intellectually curious.  The internet gives us an
> inexpensive platform that could spread the word to others.
> 4.  Have all explanatory notes written in both roman and Read's
> Alphabet just as Androcles was printed in roman and Shavian.
>
> For computer use we have the "Jerome" font, which was created about
> fifteen months ago.  I am excited about this as it gives us the
> opportunity to use the half-letters, which I found such an
> interesting facet of Read's Alphabet in handwriting as they provide
> word shapes that are more distinctive than those written with the
> full letters as in Junior Quikscript.  Jerome lets us use this
> feature in internet correspondence and teaching.  Jerome also shows
> that the letters can be joined in a "cursive" manner even
> in "printing" and remain graceful and attractive as opposed to the 
> detached and stilted Shavian.
>
> On the other hand, Jerome was the work of a person new to computer
> fonts, and it is not perfect.  I am confident that someone familiar
> with computer fonts could redesign Jerome to improve it and make it
> even easier to use while maintaining its basic style.  I believe some
> of the letters need additional work to bring them closer to their
> appearance in the Quikscript manual.  Another problem is that
> sometimes the cursor position does not appear where the next letter
> will be inserted.  This can be confusing.  And why does it only
> happen sometimes?  I think this problem is related to the use of half-
> letters, but I am not sure of this.
>
> I am interested in hearing your thoughts on this and any other
> matters connected to the use and spread of Read's Alphabet.  Thanks
> for taking the time to read this long post.
>
>
> Paige Gabhart
>
>
>
>
>
>
> To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
> Read_Alphabet-unsubscribe@egroups.com
>
> 
>

work when I have a little more time.  Jon (last name 
escapes me at th=
e moment, but he lives in Virginia, USA) put Jerome together, 
and my under=
standing is it was a first attempt on his part to work with fonts so 
my ha=
t is off to him.   I haven't heard anything from him in 
qui=
te some time, but he is still listed as a member of the group.  When J=
on 
uploaded Jerome, I was ecstatic.  I had tried to interest someone =
in the 
Shavian group  in designing a Quikscript font, but no one seem=
ed 
interested.  It was so cool to be able to type in Quikscript (I st=
ill 
prefer this name, although I acquiesced in calling this group Read_Alp=
habet to 
give recognition to Kingsley Read.)  after years of being th=
e only person I 
knew who was still using it.</FONT></FONT></SPAN></FONT></=
SPAN></FONT></DIV>

y good intentions.)  It is gratifying to see that he too has

yle=3D"FONT-FAMILY: Arial; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt">Hi,=

mailStyle18><FONT color=3Dnavy face=3DArial 
  size=3D2><SPAN

ortEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></SPAN></FONT></SPAN></P>
  <P cl=
ass=3DMsoNormal><SPAN class=3DEmailStyle18><FONT color=3Dnavy face=3DArial =

  size=3D2><SPAN 
  style=3D"FONT-FAMILY: Arial; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi=
-font-size: 12.0pt">I’m 
  new to this group and thought perhaps its =
activity had died down. So it was 
  good to hear from both Sidney and Paig=
e.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></FONT></SPAN></P>
  <P class=3DMsoNormal><SPAN class=
=3DEmailStyle18><FONT color=3Dnavy face=3DArial 
  size=3D2><SPAN 
  style=
=3D"FONT-FAMILY: Arial; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt"><![if =
!supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></SPAN></FONT></SPAN></P>
  =
<P class=3DMsoNormal><SPAN class=3DEmailStyle18><FONT color=3Dnavy face=3DA=
rial 
  size=3D2><SPAN 
  style=3D"FONT-FAMILY: Arial; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso=
-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt">I’ve 
  kept a very simple journal in Quiksc=
ript off and on for some time. I’m hoping 
  that some correspondence=
 in Quikscript will improve my skills a bit and give 
  me a “feel&#8=
221; for a better way to write in 
  English.<o:p></o:p></SPAN></FONT></SPA=
N></P>
  <P class=3DMsoNormal><SPAN class=3DEmailStyle18><FONT color=3Dnavy=
 face=3DArial 
  size=3D2><SPAN 
  style=3D"FONT-FAMILY: Arial; FONT-SIZE: =
10pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt"><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]=
><o:p></o:p></SPAN></FONT></SPAN></P>
  <P class=3DMsoNormal><SPAN class=3D=
EmailStyle18><FONT color=3Dnavy face=3DArial 
  size=3D2><SPAN 
  style=3D"=
FONT-FAMILY: Arial; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt">In 
  resp=
onse to some of Paige’s comments, I have fooled around making some ve=
ry 
  crude computer fonts using an inexpensive program called Font Creator=
 Program 
  (FCP). With this program, I’ve had difficulty designing t=
he characters so that 
  the cursor went to its intended and usual position=
. Perhaps this is what ails 
  Jerome.</SPAN></FONT></SPAN></P>
  <P class=
=3DMsoNormal><SPAN class=3DEmailStyle18><FONT color=3Dnavy face=3DArial 
  =
size=3D2><SPAN 
  style=3D"FONT-FAMILY: Arial; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-fo=
nt-size: 12.0pt"><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></SPA=
N></FONT></SPAN></P>
  <P class=3DMsoNormal><SPAN class=3DEmailStyle18><FON=
T color=3Dnavy face=3DArial 
  size=3D2><SPAN 
  style=3D"FONT-FAMILY: Aria=
l; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt">Paige, 
  can you tell me w=
hich characters you think are malformed? I could have a go at 
  improving =
them - - - but please do not get your hopes very high. Whoever made 
  Jero=
me is better at making fonts than I am.</SPAN></FONT></SPAN></P><![if !supp=
ortEmptyParas]>
  <P class=3DMsoNormal><![endif]> </P>
  <P class=3DMs=
oNormal><SPAN class=3DEmailStyle18><FONT color=3Dnavy face=3DArial 
  size=
=3D2><SPAN 
  style=3D"FONT-FAMILY: Arial; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-bidi-font-s=
ize: 12.0pt">If 
  anyone would care to, I’d like to carry on some sh=
ort, simple, correspondence 
  in Quikscript. So as a start, I’ve att=
ached a Word document with a couple of 
  sentences in Quikscript using Jer=
ome. Despite Paige’s comments, I can’t even 
  read my own Quik=
script with Jerome unless I keep the characters from running 
  together. I=
 do this by going to Word’s<o:p></o:p></SPAN></FONT></SPAN></P>

class=3DMsoNormal><SPAN class=3DEmailStyle18><FONT color=3Dnavy face=3DAria=
l 
  size=3D2><SPAN

di-font-size: 12.0pt"><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p>=

PAN></FONT></SPAN></P><![if !supportEmptyParas]>

  <P class=3DMsoNormal style=3D"MARGIN-LEFT: 0.5in=
"><TT><FONT color=3Dblack

  styl=
e=3D"COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: 'Courier New'; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; mso-fareast=
-font-family: 'Courier New'"><BR><TT>I 
  saw your message.  I know bo=
th Shaws and Kwikskript but have not seen any 
  Kwikskrit on internet.&nbs=
p; I would appreciate you letting me know if there 
  is.  Like you I =
have not had much opportunity to read it and that is as 
  important as wri=
ting it.  One way is by letter and I tried somewhat to 
  promote that=
 but no one was interested.  Like you I am not software savvy 
  and h=
ave no idea how to make up a page for Kwikskript.  Please keep in 
  t=
ouch if anyone is capable of doing something in this 
  area.</TT><BR><BR><=
TT>Sid</TT><BR><BR><BR><TT>On Mon, 11 February 2002, 
  "pgabhart" wrote:</=
TT><BR><BR><TT>> </TT><BR><TT>> Welcome to all new 
  members of the =
group and hello again to those who </TT><BR><TT>> have been 
  members f=
or awhile.  Life has not left me much time in </TT><BR><TT>> 
  rec=
ent months to do much with Read_Alphabet.  I am trying to correct 
  <=
/TT><BR><TT>> that to some degree now.  I am still having a little =

  trouble with my </TT><BR><TT>> e-mail -- my network at my office is n=
ot 
  currently operational -- so </TT><BR><TT>> do not despair if I do =
not 
  respond to an e-mail as quickly as you </TT><BR><TT>> would have =

  liked.  I will respond eventually.</TT><BR><TT>> </TT><BR><TT>&g=
t; I 
  have been using Read's Alphabet, AKA Quikscript,for roughly 26 
  <=
/TT><BR><TT>> years.  I have only had an e-mail from one other pers=
on 
  who has been </TT><BR><TT>> aware of the alphabet for that length =
of time, 
  and he seems to </TT><BR><TT>> alternate between Read's Alph=
abet and 
  Shavian.  If you or anyone you </TT><BR><TT>> know of h=
as been using 
  it for an extended period of time, let us hear </TT><BR><T=
T>> from 
  you.</TT><BR><TT>> </TT><BR><TT>> I am a firm believer=
 in the utility of 
  Read's Alphabet as well as its </TT><BR><TT>> viab=
ility as an alternative 
  alphabet that could help people in their </TT><B=
R><TT>> daily lives just as 
  Kingsley Read suggested in the Quikscript=
 Manual.</TT><BR><TT>> 
  </TT><BR><TT>> A little background on mysel=
f:  I am an attorney in 
  private practice, </TT><BR><TT>> who con=
siders himself semi-computer 
  literate.  By this I mean I am </TT><B=
R><TT>> not knowledgable about 
  specialized areas of computer science,=
 such as </TT><BR><TT>> designing 
  fonts from scratch.  On the ot=
her hand, I am not afraid to 
  </TT><BR><TT>> open up my CPU to add har=
dware, and I remember what a DOS 
  command </TT><BR><TT>> is.  Hen=
ce, the semi-literate 
  designation.  I bring this up because </TT><B=
R><TT>> there are 
  computer skills that I do not have, nor do I have t=
he time </TT><BR><TT>> 
  to learn them in the near future, that would g=
reatly enhance this 
  </TT><BR><TT>> site.  I do not doubt there a=
re people in this group 
  who already </TT><BR><TT>> possess some of th=
ese skills and who, with a 
  modest investment of </TT><BR><TT>> time, =
could help us to turn this site 
  into an attractive spot to </TT><BR><TT>=
> attract more Read's Alphabet 
  users.</TT><BR><TT>> </TT><BR><TT>&=
gt; To give you some idea of what I am 
  talking about:  Here are sev=
eral </TT><BR><TT>> things I would like to 
  see appear on this site.</=
TT><BR><TT>> 1.  A copy of the Quikscript 
  manual.  It is no=
t copyrighted so there </TT><BR><TT>> is no legal 
  prohibition I am aw=
are of that would prevent us from </TT><BR><TT>> posting 
  it.</TT><BR>=
<TT>> 2.  Texts written in Read's Alphabet.  These 
  should b=
e varying </TT><BR><TT>> lengths and levels of complexity.  
  They=
 could be original or copies </TT><BR><TT>> of literary works in the 
  =
public domain.</TT><BR><TT>> 3.  A practice area for people to writ=
e 
  back and forth to each other </TT><BR><TT>> in Read's Alphabet to g=
ain 
  experience in reading other people's </TT><BR><TT>> script. =
 I must 
  admit that even after years of occasional use, I am </TT><BR><TT=
>> not as 
  fluent at reading Read's Alphabet as I am at reading roman.=
  
  </TT><BR><TT>> Practice makes perfect, after all.  I read=
 roman 
  everyday.  I cannot </TT><BR><TT>> say that about Read's =

  Alphabet.  It is hard to get practice when the </TT><BR><TT>> on=
ly 
  person that knows the script is yourself.  I know by experience,=
 
  </TT><BR><TT>> it is not easy to get casual acquaintances to learn R=
ead's 
  Alphabet, </TT><BR><TT>> but the internet gives us the chance t=
o reach 
  people from around the </TT><BR><TT>> globe who are intellect=
ually 
  curious.  The internet gives us an </TT><BR><TT>> inexpens=
ive platform 
  that could spread the word to others.</TT><BR><TT>> 4.&n=
bsp; Have all 
  explanatory notes written in both roman and Read's </TT><B=
R><TT>> Alphabet 
  just as Androcles was printed in roman and Shavian.<=
/TT><BR><TT>> 
  </TT><BR><TT>> For computer use we have the "Jerome"=
 font, which was 
  created about </TT><BR><TT>> fifteen months ago.&nbs=
p; I am excited about 
  this as it gives us the </TT><BR><TT>> opportun=
ity to use the half-letters, 
  which I found such an </TT><BR><TT>> int=
eresting facet of Read's Alphabet 
  in handwriting as they provide </TT><B=
R><TT>> word shapes that are more 
  distinctive than those written with=
 the </TT><BR><TT>> full letters as in 
  Junior Quikscript.  Jerom=
e lets us use this </TT><BR><TT>> feature in 
  internet correspondence =
and teaching.  Jerome also shows 
  </TT><BR><TT>> that the letters=
 can be joined in a "cursive" manner even 
  </TT><BR><TT>> in "printing=
" and remain graceful and attractive as opposed 
  to the  </TT><BR><T=
T>> detached and stilted Shavian.</TT><BR><TT>> 
  </TT><BR><TT>> =
On the other hand, Jerome was the work of a person new to 
  computer </TT>=
<BR><TT>> fonts, and it is not perfect.  I am confident 
  that som=
eone familiar </TT><BR><TT>> with computer fonts could redesign 
  Jerom=
e to improve it and make it </TT><BR><TT>> even easier to use while 
  m=
aintaining its basic style.  I believe some </TT><BR><TT>> of the 
=
  letters need additional work to bring them closer to their </TT><BR><TT>&=
gt; 
  appearance in the Quikscript manual.  Another problem is that 
=
  </TT><BR><TT>> sometimes the cursor position does not appear where the=
 next 
  letter </TT><BR><TT>> will be inserted.  This can be confu=
sing.  
  And why does it only </TT><BR><TT>> happen sometimes?&nbs=
p; I think this 
  problem is related to the use of half-</TT><BR><TT>> =
letters, but I am not 
  sure of this.</TT><BR><TT>> </TT><BR><TT>> I=
 am interested in hearing 
  your thoughts on this and any other </TT><BR><=
TT>> matters connected to the 
  use and spread of Read's Alphabet.&nbsp=
; Thanks </TT><BR><TT>> for taking 
  the time to read this long post.</=
